x_snc_hack4good_0_hack4good_proposal.problem_statement:
During health emergencies and humanitarian crises, medical supplies donated by NGOs and global partners often face tracking and visibility issues. Shipments get delayed, misplaced, or duplicated, and there’s little real time insight into where supplies are, how much is available, or what’s urgently needed.
Manual record keeping and lack of transparency lead to waste, stockouts, and unequal distribution, especially in remote or developing regions. This reduces the effectiveness of aid operations and delays life-saving deliveries.

x_snc_hack4good_0_hack4good_proposal.solution_proposal:
How do you envision the ideal solution to this  problem?

 

Which ServiceNow products or capabilities would be used?

MedTrack would be a ServiceNow-based automation platform that manages the end to end flow of donated medical supplies.

How It Works:

  1. Donation Registration: NGOs or donors log incoming supplies via a web portal.

  2. Workflow Automation: Each shipment is assigned a unique ID and tracked through customs, warehousing, and delivery.

  3. AI & Predictive Intelligence: Detects shortages, delays, or duplication risks.

  4. IntegrationHub: Connects with logistics APIs (FedEx, DHL, or local couriers) for real-time updates.

  5. Dashboards: Show current inventory, delivery progress, and stock predictions for better planning.

ServiceNow Products / Capabilities to Use:

  • App Engine: for building the donation tracking and management system.
  • Flow Designer: to automate logistics workflows.
  • Predictive Intelligence: for forecasting shortages or delays.
  • IntegrationHub: to link shipping and warehouse systems.
  • Performance Analytics: to visualize supply movement and performance metrics.

 

Are there any technical dependencies for the proposed solution?

  • Integration with logistics APIs (e.g., DHL, UPS, local transport systems).
  • Barcode or QR code scanning system for package tracking.
  • Cloud database access for centralized inventory management.
  • AI/ML model for demand prediction and anomaly detection.
  • Secure network infrastructure for data exchange among partners.

 

What challenges would you foresee in implementing this idea?

  • Data standardization across multiple NGOs and logistics partners.
  • Limited connectivity in rural or crisis regions affecting real-time tracking.
  • Integration difficulties with external courier systems.
  • Training and adoption for staff unfamiliar with digital tools.
  • Ensuring transparency and data security between organizations with different policies.
